Starbucks coffee is one of those love-it or hate-it products. The Starbucks roast is halfway between a French roast (dark and strong) and a more delicate medium roast. I happen to adore Starbucks coffee, so I was happy to have the chance to try this one.

It is unmistakably Starbucks. The vanilla flavor is very subtle, not strong at all, but adding cream and sugar does bring out that lovely vanilla taste and aroma.

Not sure what else I can say about this coffee. Does 'Yum' pretty much cover it?

Summary: If Vanilla is the flavor, why is it the THIRD ingredient after "coffee"?
Text:
I tend to be a regular coffee drinker - 3 to 4 cups per day. And periodically drink flavored coffee. Most are too flavored for me. I like a dark roast (though not as dark as French Roast). I DO like Starbucks' varietals and SOME blends.

So, I was hoping for the best of both worlds when Amazon sent me the 1lb package to try. But it didn't live up to expectations.

The coffee was a lighter roast than normal - more like Dunkin Donuts. And the Vanilla flavor didn't taste like just vanilla. So I read the package. Though it says "Vanilla and other Natural Flavors" on the front of the package the ingredients list reads as follows" Ground coffee, Natural Flavor (with corn maltodextrine, vegetable Glycerin), Gound Vanilla Beans, Indian Sarsaparilla Root". Hmm. corn sugar and a natural vegetable product BEFORE the Vanilla? And Sarsaparilla? It's not in the name. That explained the different taste and the aftertaste I got. How about just giving us coffee and vanilla beans? This is to be premium coffee.

I think I'll pass on this line of flavors in the future. Coffee preference is a subjective thing. There are lines at Dunkin Donuts and Starbucks as well as McDonalds. And Maxwell House still sells well.

So you may or not agree with me but I just want folks who read this review to know the ingredients when they buy this "Natural Fusion" product from Starbucks.

Steve Ramm (who generally reviews CDs, books and DVDs but DOES drink coffee too!)
"Anything Phonographic"

Summary: So-so coffee sold by union-busting Starbucks
Text:
I'm not actually a food reviewer. I'll do my best here, but don't expect anything special.

This coffee is entirely decent, but tastes to me a little too much like I'm trying to drink candy. The flavor is less about a 'hint' of vanilla and more about sort of rolling your nose around in a vanilla extract smell. The coffee taste itself, underneath all that vanilla, somehow manages to come off musty, if that makes any sense. It's almost a little too much in the morning, though I suppose it'd make a good dessert coffee.

Then there's the Starbucks factor, of course. If you're socially conscious enough to care that this is labeled as a fair trade item, you probably also care about the fact that Starbucks is a union-busting company. All in all, you ought to take your fair trade business elsewhere, as it doesn't make much sense to try to support fair trade on the one hand, while contributing to the abuse of American workers on the other.

ProfileName: Christina Paul "Live like you MEAN it!!"
Summary: A little less vanilla than you'd expect
Text: Starbucks Natural Fusions vanilla flavoured coffee is the same consistently strong taste you would expect from the Starbucks brand. The dark roasted taste is consistently strong to the point where it almost overwhelms the vanilla flavouring that was added.  You can taste the vanilla only slightly.  I do use a French press rather than a drip coffee maker for my coffee,letting it steep several minutes in order to maximize the flavour.  This particular batch of coffee came pre-ground and I am one of those hard core cofee drinkers who prefers whole bean coffee,  grinding the beans only when they are ready to be used. While the taste is pleasant enough, and it was a nice change from the usual French or Turkish roast that I drink, I am not sure that I would go out of my way to buy this particular coffee again.

Summary: Better coffees out there, not much vanilla flavor
Text: This coffee is slightly better than your average supermarket coffee.  The vanilla flavor is very faint.  If you are looking for vanilla coffee, adding vanilla syrup to your coffee is a better choice.  I prefer fresh roasted coffee from Peets or my local coffee shop.  This is not bad, but lacks that fresh roasted taste.  I rate it average.

Summary: Decent tasting coffee, just a bit bitter for my taste
Text:
I am a huge vanilla flavor fan. I love anything vanilla flavored. So naturally, I figured that I would love this coffee. The aroma is great when I open the package and dumped the ground coffee into my coffeemaker. I had high expectations for this.

The coffee itself, once it is made is actually only decent tasting. I could only taste a very small hint of vanilla in it and it might have been because of my creamer and not the actual coffee itself. It was a bit bitter compared to other coffees that I have had and very rich. I usually take my coffee with cream and a small amount of sweetner and never really had problems with it being still too bitter.

Next time, I guess I'll just use more cream and sweetner. Don't get me wrong, this is not completely horrible and I still enjoy Starbucks. It just surprised me as how bitter it was.

Summary: Coffee and Real Vanilla A True Fit
Text:
I have been a Vanilla Latte devotee for several years, just ask my local coffee cafe. Only Vanilla Latte, I might add. I will at Christmas try a Gingerbread but always revert back to vanilla. I am also a fan of vanilla ice cream. I am a coffee lover, and went through the flavored coffee phase a few years ago, but quickly reverted to my regular coffee. I was very interested to see the Starbucks Vanilla Fusion on the market. Couldn't wait to try it.

The package is very attractive, a subtle green with a picture of a vanilla bean on the front. I have discovered that coffee rarely comes in pound packages nowadays. The pound was decreased to 12 ounces for the price of a pound, and the Vanilla Fusion is 11 ounces. Opening the package and a very subtle smell of vanilla and coffee is inhaled. I made my coffee in my trusty Cuisinart Coffee maker, and used the usual directions. I poured a cup of the coffee and an aroma of coffee and vanilla lingered. I usually taste new coffee, black, to get the full flavor and this did not disappoint. The taste is a strong medium dark roast. A mellow vanilla flavor blends. The after taste had a darker roast flavor. I then tried it with a little half and half, and this was delicious. My vanilla latte has come home to roost! There are no chemicals in this coffee, but real vanilla beans are roasted with arabica beans and produce a marvelous taste. Not too strong and with a subtle taste of vanilla.

The Starbucks Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored could be one of the best flavored coffees I have had. This will become a staple in my home. I am anxious to try their caramel flavored coffee.

Highly Recommended. prisrob 11-27-10

Starbucks VIA Iced Coffee by Starbucks Coffee

Starbucks Africa Kitamu Coffee, Ground, 12-Ounce Bags (Pack of 3)

I normally buy Starbucks so I was excited to try this flavor. The coffee is mild. Normally with Starbucks, what is advertised is usually the next level. So mild usually tastes medium, medium tastes bold and bold pretty much removes all tissue from your mouth. This truly is a mild brew.

Also with Starbucks I normally HATE the way the unbrewed coffee smells. This was an exception and it didn't smell too bad.

When I brewed as I normally would it was a smooth cup of coffee with a subtle hint of vanilla. The next day my husband brewed it with an extra scoop to make it stronger and it was a hot mess.

In short, go light on the coffee when you brew and you will get an excellent tasting cup of smooth & subtle vanilla flavor.

Summary: Vanilla flavored Starbucks coffee is not bad
Text:
First, I have to confess that I don't care for flavored coffees. However, vanilla is one of my favorite flavors in other food products. So, when I came across this coffee, I thought I would give it a try.

I have been consuming this coffee for the past 3 days and I can only say that I can tolerate this coffee. It didn't change my opinion of flavored coffees. I will still avoid them.

I will return to regular coffee from now.

Summary: Yes, I do like flavored coffees BUT.....
Text:
I just want to preface this review by noting that I do stop into Starbucks and get flavored coffees (current favorite, Peppermint Mocha, whipped cream on top). So I had positive expectations of a vanilla flavored coffee. Unfortunately, this was among the worst Starbucks blends I've ever tasted. Just to give it a fair shot, I tried brewing and drinking it four different ways:

1.Mild with no sugar or cream
2. Strong with no sugar or cream
3. Mild with sugar and cream
4. Strong with sugar and cream

I also had friends taste test this. We all hated it. We couldn't choke it down as it was truly bitter and unpleasant. Maybe we got a bad batch or bag. At this point, we have nearly a whole bag left and I'm feeling guilty about wasting it. But there is no way I'm going to brew another pot of coffee and try to create a tasty brew. I tend to like my coffee extremely strong but even making it overly strong did not make it better. Yes, the vanilla flavor came through but it wasn't a good addition to a possibly decent coffee (without the vanilla).

Vanilla flavored coffee happens to be my favorite. I like to drink it hot or cold all year round and prefer the 'soft' aftertaste to other roasts. I can't say that I notice any difference in the 'natural fusion' as to the taste of other flavored coffees but it was definitely superior to coffee that was flavored after it was brewed.

Zeb Kantrowitz

Summary: Suprised by how good it is
Text:
I'm an avid coffee drinker, but I stick to the basics: lattes, french roast drip, espresso. Only rarely do I drink coffee with flavor added. But when I do, it's typically vanilla, so I thought this might be a decent product to have on hand during the holidays as an addition to my usual dark-roast, whole beans.

I am drinking a cup as I type this and it's really good. The coffee itself has the full-bodied, robust taste I like. The vanilla flavoring is subtle and pleasant. It doesn't taste artificial and leaves no after taste. It's definitely a nice change from my usual coffee and feels festive.

The Amazon price for two bags seems reasonable to me for Starbuck's coffee. Yes, it may be more expensive than other brands, but I think it's worth the delicate balance of flavors you get from the product.

Buy it for the amazing smell.  I opened the bag and was in love.  I looked in there and it reminded me of a fine tea blend with flecks of different roots and beans etc.  The coffee smelled great while it was brewing.  At first when I took a sip it was all I had hoped for.  But then it hit the back of my tongue and I tasted a slight acidic flavor.  I hate that in a coffee.  It was not strongly acidic, very slight, and probably plenty of sugar would nullify the acid, but I don't want tons of sugar.  All in all I would say I like it, but it's not my favorite coffee.

I must admit, I wasn't expecting much when I ordered this thru the Vine program. I was wary of anything that is "pre-flavored". However, I was pleasantly surprised. When you open up the bag the smell is wonderful. And the taste is complex. Some people have complained that the vanilla flavor is not pronounced enough, but I find it to be just right. It is definitely there, but not overwhelming. There is another nice flavor in there which I couldn't quite place, but after reading the ingredient list on the bag I assume it is the Sarsaparilla Root. The coffee is slightly bitter, which adds to the complex flavor. (There is a yin-yang thing going on with the sweeter flavors.) I like a very strong, dark roast and I find that this falls into that category although Starbucks advertises it as a medium roast. Overall, I think this is a winner.

Summary: Not real big on vanilla but this is good...
Text:
I'm not huge on plain coffee but I do enjoy making myself Cafe Mochas and this is wonderful for that. I've drank this plain as well and thought that was really good too. I was a little worried that the smell would put me off because I'm one of the few people that don't like the smell of vanilla but this wasn't overwhelming at all. I actually liked the smell of this.

Smells great and tastes really good. What more do you need? I highly recommend this coffee.

Summary: Not as good as their unflavored coffees.
Text:
I am a flat-out fiend for good coffee. I ordered Starbucks by mail well before they had a string of coffee shops, and I'd venture to guess that were you to order a vanilla latte there, this is not what you would get.

I basically never buy flavored coffees, having learned from a friend who worked for a local gourmet coffee company that if you want flavored coffee, you add the flavoring after it is brewed. Because many delicate natural ingredients are destroyed by the heat required to brew coffee properly most flavored coffees are chemical. I would not purchase a chemically flavored coffe, or drink it except as aq last resort (i.e., stranded at an airport). I applaud Starbucks for the effort to make a naturally flavored coffee, and on thinking about it, vanilla beans seem like one of the better candidates to stand up to the heat; after all, they are used in baking at even higher heat.
However, this effort falls somewhat flat, or maybe I should say sharp. While it smells just wonderful when you open the bag, the brewed coffee is bitter with only a faint odor remaining to remind you that it is flavored with vanilla. I am not familar enough with the chemistry of vanilla (would have to consult On Food and Cooking: The Science and Lore of the Kitchen to see if vanilla is fat or water solable. Maybe it's the butter in cakes and cookies which absorbs the flavor.... but whatever it is that does it in baked goods is missing here.

I suspect that Starbucks released this to combat the rise of Dunkin Donuts coffees. But to my mind that is like a steak house worrying over all the people who flock to McDonalds. I am hoping that Starbucks maintains the standards which allow us to look to them for a reliably good cup of coffee. This is a disappointment from a company which knows good coffee, and which should know better. It would be a lot better had they packaged the coffee with single serve packets of vanilla sugar.

The coffee is ground for drip brewers as is most of their ground coffee. While it is described as a medium roast, it tastes like a French roast (but not a good one). Because of the larger grind, I am guessing it can be used with a French press. I will give that a try to see if the vanilla beans hold up any better, and return to this review forthwith. It was not terrific brewed in a good drip brewer, which is, how I suspect most people would make pre-ground coffee.

Summary: raises the bar for scented coffee
Text:
I was very excited to try this. I brewed it 3 ways: vacuum, press, drip.

This a relatively fine grind. I'd call it the finest limit of drip coffee. Beyond that, we're getting into espresso territory.

Against my better judgement, I tried it in my French Press. The fine particles plug up the steel mesh making the plunger difficult to press. The finer particles got into the brew. There was a very thick sludge at the bottom of the cup. Flavor-wise, it was intense but not bad. There was a slight bitter taste and a silky texture which I suspect was from the dust in suspension. So I ran it through a cone filter. The resulting brew was still intense but lost all of the vanilla aroma. The texture was too thin. It basically became a better than average cup of "diner coffee". Easy to drink, dark & tasty, but nothing to write home about.

I expected great results from the vacuum brewer. While brewing, it filled the kitchen with vanilla, but when I tasted the coffee, there was only a hint of it. I don't think it brewed long enough to pick up the vanilla, or maybe it was so hot the vanilla vaporized rather than dissolve. In any case, the final product was only slightly better than the pressed-then-filtered coffee above. Not recommended.

Surprisingly, the best results came from my drip machine. I used the freebie Gevalia gave me with membership (yeah, I'm a sucker for free stuff). I'm drinking the stuff now as I write this review and it's exceptional. I only used 2 Tbsp to 6 servings of water and the taste is just about right. It has a rich mouth-feel, a fair amount of vanilla aroma, a robust coffee taste.

I've bought and tasted flavored coffees before and have come to the conclusion that most of the manufacturers are just masking cheap, dry, tasteless coffee with deceptively sweet aromas. Those coffees rarely taste like coffee and never taste like the additional flavor, which is why I call them "scented coffee" rather than "flavored coffee". So color me jaded. But the stuff from my drip machine actually TASTES LIKE VANILLA! And maybe my mind is playing tricks on me, but I'm getting a hint of ice-cream too! I'm drinking it black, no sugar so it's pretty fascinating.

BOTTOM LINE: When brewed 2:6 in an average #4 drip coffee-maker, you get a delicious coffee treat with the usual Starbucks buzz to brighten up your work-day.

Update 12/7/10: Now my law-enforcement, black coffee, no-frills husband wants me to always get this coffee. It's that good, and the vanilla just sortof creates a smoothness, or fullness that is very satisfying.

I normally do not drink flavored coffee, and I don't add any sweetener to my coffee, either. I hate that chemical taste found with those artificially flavored coffees. I tried this because it said it has all natural flavors. They grind up actual vanilla beans and add that to the grounds. You can see them!

Smelled amazing! Wonderful flavor. Not overpowering. The vanilla (& sassparillo) give the coffee a delightful smoothness. Absolutely no artificial, chemical taste. You don't take a sip and say "wow, this is definitely flavored coffee." This will make a perfect after-dinner coffee, excellent in the morning, and any time of day. I'll be getting this again.

Purchased this coffee because I enjoy vanilla and coffee, and enjoyed a previously purchased bag of Starbucks ground coffee. It sounded good, but I was wrong. It just tastes like bad coffee. There's no vanilla in there anywhere. This would be fine if it still tasted alright, but I feel sad for wasting my money on this product.

ProfileName: Gina Pera "Is It You, Me, or Adult A.D.D.?, a...
Summary: Not a fan of "flavored" coffees but like this
Text:
When it comes to coffee, I'm something of a purist. I expect it to taste like coffee, not hazelnuts, cinnamon, etc.

Adding flavors to coffee just seems to confuse and overwhelm my taste buds.

This coffee, however, provided the Starbucks coffee taste I enjoy with a slight vanilla "enhancement." Tastes real, not artificial.

I liked it, although I can't brew it as strong as Starbucks recommends.

The vanilla added a nice fragrance to the coffee (and, unlike what others have said, I -did- definitely taste the vanilla). Just remember Starbucks is formulated to be mixed with milk. It's really not at it's best when it''s black--with or without vanilla.

My wife and I love Starbucks coffee, so when had the opportunity to try their vanilla flavor, we took it. Just made a pot of it, and it is fabulous. I used to use sugar in my coffee, but this is perfectly sweet enough as it is. (Less sugar is healthier for you.) The only thing I would suggest is NOT following the directions of 2 tablespoons per 6 oz. of water... we use only 1 and it is plenty strong enough. But I guess that's a personal taste thing. Highly recommended.

Summary: Milder roast, not bitter, and without any strong smell! Winner!
Text:
I like flavored coffee's but not as much as a good nice light to medium roast blend of just regular ol' Java. I find flavored coffee's to just be a bit too much. In general I actually don't like Starbucks beans that much because I find the coffee bitter with an aftertaste that stays with me for too long - and I get heartburn. Not fun. The key word on this package that got me to try it was Natural.

I might be the only one but the biggest problem I have with flavored type coffee is not only the cloying taste but the extremely strong smell. If I want that strong a smell in my house I'll buy candles or spray. Usually, after about a fourth of the cup, I just don't want to drink much more - or smell it. I was very pleasantly surprised to find this coffee carries the trace of smell but it is neither strong nor overpowering. The taste follow suit - this is not a heavy roast and it does not have any bitter aftertaste. I found it exceedingly pleasant and finished the whole cup. In fact I found it so good that I would likely drink it on a regular basis. It is just perfect for me. Amazon's price is good as well. I'm kind of surprising myself by saying there's nothing not to like about this one. Give it a try!

The smell of coffee is the first step to a great morning.  Right out of the bag you can smell the deep richness of this Starbucks coffee.  The hint of Vanilla just makes it that much more enticing.  I'm sure that there are purists out there that would not hear of drinking a flavored coffee.  But if you are inclined to a subtle bump in flavor that wistfully plays with your taste buds, then you might want to try this coffee.  It is excellent.

ProfileName: James Beswick "In my day, we had 9 planets."
Summary: A very smooth coffee with a subtle flavor
Text: Full disclosure: I don't generally enjoy Starbucks coffee, mainly because it often tastes bitter at the stores, and I haven't had a flavored coffee in quite a while. For both those reasons, I was pleasantly surprised with this pack of Starbucks Vanilla, which balances the flavor with a mellow, smooth brew. Made in a French press, it's the perfect afternoon shot-in-the-arm, and the vanilla really isn't as over-powering as I expected. From a pricing standpoint, it's well priced for two bags, and I can definitely see myself stocking up for holidays, which seem to be the perfect time of year for flavored coffee.

Summary: An unfortunate truth about vanilla coffee...
Text: ...is that it tastes like vanilla coffee. Any richness or flavor inherent in the coffee itself is obliterated by the chemical bite of the fake vanilla. I just don't think there's any way around it. Whether the coffee is decent Starbucks brand (and I'm a Starbucks drinker, admittedly), cheap grocery store brand or some kind of high-end bean, the result is the same: it's always going to taste like something you'd drink for free at a continental breakfast bar at a cut-rate hotel.

Summary: Unique Real Vanilla Essence, Not Overly Flavored Yet Definite
Text: I basically gave up "flavored" coffee years ago after a brief love affair with coffee beans laced with chocolate, vanilla, raspberry, gran marnier, etc. But this Vanilla Starbucks is different than the flavored coffees I used to drink. This does taste like a nice, full bodied coffee (and not bitter) with just a subtle hint of real vanilla taste and aroma. It reminds me more of a cup of coffee after adding a shake or two of the real vanilla powder. Its very satisfying. While I still prefer the dark italian roasts this is a real treat and fits perfectly into the holiday season. Excellent!

Summary: Good if you like flavored coffees - Americano review
Text:
I ordered this to try as a different sort of coffee.

My brewing method:

I normally make Americano, which is an espresso with extra water. I have always just let my manual espresso machine continue to brew after it's normal double espresso, and the results are very good. I generally use a darker, bolder roast, and since I have tried Starbucks bold roast before, It felt this might make a nice change. This method of brewing really brings out the quality (or lack thereof) in a coffee.

The results
This coffee makes a lot less "crema", which is what espresso machines put out as a sort of light brown colored foam at the top of the coffee. As to taste, it is (as expected) a lot less bold. My initial thought was that I found the vanilla to be a bit sharp or bitter, but then I'm using an espresso machine, not a french press or brew machine. At the same time, I didn't taste the coffee as much as I might prefer.

However, after sipping a bit over half the cup, I find that it is actually a pleasant drink; by the time I emptied my cup, I decided that I will make more of this coffee - as a change of pace, not as my primary flavor or brand. I can taste the vanilla, and a bit of the coffee. Perhaps this means that the blend is very good - if they were aiming for exact balance. I would characterize it as a "vanilla and coffee drink" rather than a "vanilla flavored coffee" because that more accurately describes the overall flavor.

Summary:
Flavored coffees are a world to themselves - one either likes the concept of putting additional flavor in coffee, or one doesn't - there isn't much in between. For anyone who likes flavored coffees, I think this one would be suitable for daily use. Recommended if you like this sort of combination, but not if one prefers more coffee taste and less vanilla addition.

I can't count the times I've bought a flavored coffee, opened the bag and inhaled the incredible aroma only to be disappointed that, once brewed the special "flavor" either isn't detectable or conversely completely overpowers the coffee itself . Few coffee companies achieve that "happy medium" of providing specialty flavor without compromising the integrity of the coffee itself.

Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla is the exception. This mostly medium roast has an unmistakable but not obnoxious vanilla perfume upon opening. I was pleased to find that upon tasting, there is indeed a distinct vanilla note to the coffee, but one that is content to stay in the background and compliment rather than dominate. It is not overly sweet and wears on the palate well over the course of a few cups.

I you are the type who doctors your coffee up with flavored sugars and/or creamers the subtleties of this coffee may not matter to you. But for those who are interested in actually tasting the coffee, this is a good buy.

Summary: Here's what many aren't understanding about this coffee
Text:
They aren't understanding that the vanilla flavor is *supposed* to be subtle. If you don't believe me, just read the bag because it states this quite clearly. I've seen many reviews where the reviewer is dinging the rating because the flavor is subtle and that's not fair in my opinion because that's what Starbucks is trying to accomplish. And for those who say that there is no vanilla flavor, I strongly disagree. It's there but it's subtle, which is the entire idea here folks.

Along those same likes, I thought I'd compare the subtle flavors of the Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla coffee to the more pronounced flavors of the Melitta Pariaian Vanilla coffee. So I brewed two cups and then sampled each side-by-side. Following are my impressions of each coffee.

Cost: While prices change all of the time, as of this writing, Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla Coffee is selling for $0.59 per ounce. The Melitta Parisian Vanilla Coffee is selling for $0.58 per ounce. So in essence, the price is roughly the same between the two.

Color/Roast: The color looks about the same between the two. It's a medium roast or roughly a city roast for those who know what that means. In the past I've felt as if Starbucks overroasts some of their coffee. Fortunately, that does not appear to be the case with their Natural Vanilla Coffee.

Grind: The grind is also about the same. Melitta calls it an extra fine grind but both are probably somewhere between a fine grind and an extra fine grind. I brewed both cups in my Jura S7 espresso machine in the Cafe Americano style, which is basically hot water added to a shot or two of espresso.

Aroma in the bag: Starbucks mostly smells like very good quality coffee. The scent of vanilla is present but subtle. What vanilla scent is there is reminds one of fresh and natural ingredients. The Melitta has more of a pronounced vanilla scent. The Melitta's scent is pleasant but slightly artificial to my nose.

Aroma in the cup: The vanilla scent is very subtle with respect to Starbucks Natural Vanilla. The Melitta Parisian Vanilla has a stronger, but not overpowering scent. There's more vanilla scent in the Melitta cup to be sure.

Flavor: Both coffees are very pleasant, although I'd characterize Starbucks Natural Vanilla as being a very good quality coffee with a subtle hint of vanilla versus Melitta's Parisian Vanilla coffee being a vanilla-flavored coffee, if that makes sense. While I still like and recommend the Melitta, I think I like it a little bit less now that I've tried the Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla Coffee. That's because the Starbucks brew has a fresher and more natural aroma and flavor. But again, the Starbucks coffee is far more subtle than the Melitta coffee. For some, that will be a good thing and others will undoubtedly wish for a more forward vanilla flavor.

Ingredients: The Starbucks Natural Vanilla lists their ingredients as "Ground Coffee, Natural Flavors, Ground Vanilla Beans & Indian Sarsaparilla Root" (with Corn Maltodextrin & Vegetable Glycerin added). Melitta doesn't tell you what's in their blend. I visited Melitta's website in an effort to determine what sort of ingredients are used to flavor their Parisian Vanilla. They use words like "rich" and "smooth and creamy", but nothing more specific that I could find. So I am going to assume that Starbucks uses ingredients that I would consider to be of a superior quality to the ingredients used to flavor the Melitta Parisian Vanilla.

Recommendations: One thing that I like to do is to buy non-flavored beans and simply add a teaspoon or tablespoon of fresh vanilla to a cup of non-flavored beans. So this is also an option. If you go this route, use only real vanilla and not the artificial stuff. Now with respect to these flavored coffees, they're both very good. Tasting the two coffees side-by-side gave me a good opportunity to compare the two. While I still like the Melitta Parisian Vanilla, I prefer the subtle character and fresh ingredients of the Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla coffee. If you prefer a coffee with a more pronounced but not overpowering vanilla flavor, go with Melitta. If you prefer a well-balanced coffee with a subtle but fresh and natural vanilla flavor, you might prefer the Starbucks version. If you're not sure, consider trying each and decide for yourself, as they're not terribly expensive. But in the end, I do think that they are both very good.

If you enjoy Starbucks coffee, than you already know that this is well worth the money. So buy it! If you are (somehow!) new to the franchise or this specific product, read on ...

Now, I'm almost inclined to rate this product as though it didn't read "vanilla." To be perfectly frank, the vanilla taste is nearly undetectable (and I have a fairly sensitive nose and palette). I see that multiple reviewers here have registered similar "complaints." Surely, I think Starbucks would have been wise to label the product as having "a hint of vanilla." So, please know that this is not a true vanilla flavor (just in case you are searching for a brew to compliment a particular dessert or breakfast.)

Nonetheless, as far as the standards of coffee, this one has near perfect acidity, a lovely aroma, and bright flavor.

If you need a little more sweetness, add raw sugar (Sugar In The Raw/Unrefined is a great choice and can be found just about anywhere).

Bottom-line: do not buy this coffee expecting a rich vanilla flavor and you'll be fine. Very tasty!

Post-script: I saw that a chef noted that Starbucks was not created to drink black. While I never use milk in my coffee, I decided to take this professional's advice. I added some (soy) milk and found that the very slight "bitterness" was entirely gone. (Now I have reinstated the product's missing star!)

I don't know how to start this off, this coffee tastes nothing like I have tasted before...That is how wonderful it is...If you love Vanilla this is for you to try...I especially love doing Ice Coffee in the morning...Thank you Starbucks for putting this out...YAY!
Purchased only as a filler for an order, had 7.50 off a two pack on top of that still not worth it, I had much rather have 8Oclock. Way overpriced and had little vanilla flavor.

Summary: I can smell the vanilla, can't taste it
Text:
Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla coffee isn't all it's cracked up to be. You can clearly smell the vanilla when you open the bag but..... brewing destroys it

After I brewed a pot, Could not smell the vanilla nor taste it. The Vanilla was gone.

Save your money. There's no vanilla flavor, just vanilla scent in the coffee grounds fresh out of the bag

... consistently bad.

--- EDITED 11-27-2010 ---
Has anyone read the ingredients? This product contains corn maltodextrin (which I have an allergy to), vegetable glycerin, and Indian sarsaparilla root. This is probably where the odd and nasty taste I am getting is coming from.

And why the hell are these in coffee? Shouldn't it be JUST coffee and whatever flavoring is added?

Way to go Starbucks! 1 star!
--- EDIT ---

I've tried many different Starbucks coffees, from morning blends to more flavored coffees and not one have I enjoyed or liked.

The vanilla flavor in Starbucks Natural Fusions is a joke. When you first open the bag you are hit with this amazing aroma of nice fragrant coffee with a delightful hint of vanilla. When brewing, you completely loose the vanilla smell. And once tasted, the vanilla is GONE. And I don't think I should be expected to have to add something (be it milk, cream, or some other product) to bring out the flavor of the coffee. A good coffee can stand alone straight from the pot.

No matter how weak or strong I made it, it had a not so pleasant taste to it. I'm thinking that it had a lot of quakers in it before the coffee was ground, thus this odd taste was present.

The only redeeming quality is the look and design of the bag, initial smell, and the fact that it gives me my caffeine for the day, even if I have to chug it.

Back to the drawing board Starbucks and come back with a better tasting blend.

Pros:
Smells great!
Didn't get a bitter taste from it (oddly enough).

Cons:
Didn't taste like vanilla by any stretch.
Isn't all that palatable to my or three other peoples taste.
Pricey for mediocre coffee.

I love this particular brand and taste! The vanilla not only has a great aroma when brewing, but the flavor is just as awesome! I love coffee and usually always change what i'm drinking because of the vast variety out there; but I honestly have to say that this is probably the 3rd time in a row i've purchased this particular brand and flavor! I love it!... Nothing more :)

Summary: If Flavor is Your Choice, Nothing Wrong Here
Text:
Firstly, I do drink a fair amount of coffee during the winter months.

Nevertheless, I tend not to drink flavored coffee. This is ground, flavored coffee. Starbucks has not previously offered flavored coffees themselves because they know it will contaminate unflavored coffee in a grinder. They are getting around this by only selling the coffee pre-ground, therefore, no customer will ever request it to be ground.

When first opened, the quality is decent despite being pre-ground. However, I do find, the quality of the product slips away fairly quickly being a ground coffee.

Furthermore, again, I am not a particular fan of flavored coffees. If I need a sweetener or flavor, I'd prefer to add it myself. Nevertheless, this vanilla flavored product is not terribly unpleasant. I was able to enjoy it on a quiet morning or two when I wasn't demanding the very best.

If flavored coffees is your thing, you will likely have no problems at all!

Starbucks is high quality coffee, and this is no exception. If you are looking for a high quality vanilla flavored ground coffee, this is a great one to try. The packaging is beautiful and the price is reasonable for home brewed coffee.

My wife LOVES this brand from Starbucks. We use this in a pretty expensive coffee maker, and she tells me this is right up there with the more expensive bands of coffee she has tried. The vanilla comes though but not too strongly. Robust flavor with a nice complement of Vanilla. Worth the price!
I gave this as a gift to my mother, who is a fan of vanilla flavored coffee.  She said she enjoyed it, that it had a nice vanilla smell and a smooth taste.  She said she would buy it again.

Summary: Good coffee with pretty natural vanilla flavor
Text:
Full disclosure: I'm not a fan of flavored coffees. I generally find them frivolous when I'm feeling generous and a sign of moral weakness when I'm not. In fact, I chose this coffee from Amazon vine by accident, and only finally tried it months later, when I ran out of regular coffee and was desperate. I stored it in the freezer in the meantime, so it would be as fresh as possible and I'd be giving it a fair shake, since ground coffee can lose flavor so quickly.

I tried to temper my review to judge this product as someone who doesn't have a moral objection to flavored coffee (no one with my preference would buy it in real life, so it's unfair to judge it by the standards of someone who dislikes flavored coffee), and just rated the overall quality of the coffee and the strength and quality of the vanilla flavor.

I drink my coffee black, whether iced or hot.

The verdict: I'm still no fan of flavored coffee. But this coffee is good enough, and the vanilla flavor is strong but not cloying. I would definitely tolerate it for the sake of pleasing a guest who liked flavored coffees--which is more than I've ever been able to say for a flavored coffee before (typically, flavoring seems to be a compensation for crappy coffee, not an addition to good coffee). Hot, I found it tolerable (=very good, if I actually wanted vanilla in my coffee). And iced, it was actually verging on pleasant. It has a very faint acrid afternote, almost like chickory coffee, which I think would be dispelled or improved with milk, which most flavored coffee drinkers I know favor anyway.

While I still wouldn't drink it on purpose if there was any regular coffee in the house, I didn't find it to be the abomination I expected, and I feel confident that it would be well received by flavored coffee lovers, so I give it 4 stars for quality and strength, and its expected success with people who like this stuff.

I don't drink flavored coffee often but I was completely disappointed by this coffee. No detectable vanilla flavor at all. I agree with what another reviewer said: In a blind taste test, I'd be hard pressed to identify this coffee as vanilla.

I am no effete coffee genius who can go into the infinite spectrum of points about what makes a coffee good or not so good, but I do appreciate an astounding, wake-me-up twist on an old theme. This isn't it.

While achieving everything an adequate coffee should provide, Starbuck's Vanilla Natural Fusions Ground Coffee is just that - adequate coffee. I was not blown away by subtle essences of vanilla; it did smell pretty good while brewing, which I suppose is the aim of coffee in general (one of the Top Ten Smells in the world, IMO, is a good coffee brewing up), but the flavor wasn't any more spectacular than any other coffee on the market. I would categorize it as robust, full-bodied, and - good. Not wow, do-cartwheels, jump-up-and-down...just that - good. Maybe the vanilla essence needs to be a little more noticeable, but for flavored coffee, I prefer Gloria Jean's.

Let me start by saying that normally I avoid flavored coffee. However, this flavored coffee is delicious! It has a really nice vanilla smell and the taste is just as good as it smells. It tastes as if you put a drop of fine vanilla into an already good cup of coffee! Treat yourself to a cup of this, you won't regret it! YUM!

Summary: It good coffee, but it's not vanilla
Text: I've brewed my way through a bag of this stuff now and it's good coffee.  Not bitter, good mouthfeel, nice color and, of course, smells great while it's brewing.  Pretty much worthy of the Starbucks label.  No vanilla though... maybe a little hint while brewing (?) maybe that's just because I was hoping to smell it?

I'm not sure why, but I do not like this as much as some other flavored coffees.  The flavor is very  noticeable, but it does not remind me of vanilla the way I would like.  I associate vanilla extract with the chocolate chip cookies I use it in, or rich vanilla ice cream.  I did not get that flavor in this coffee.  I won't buy it again.

As usual, Starbucks hit the mark.  This coffee has a nice, smooth flavor.  It smells fantastic!  If you are looking for a twist on your usual coffee brew, try this out.  It is isn't overwhelmingly vanilla, just subtle, but it does give it a nice change from the ordinary.  If you are a Starbucks fan, you won't be disappointed!

Many flavored coffees use artificial flavorings. Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla contains ground vanilla beans and Indian sarsaparilla root, and I think the result is the most authentic vanilla-flavored coffee I've tasted. I used the ground coffee with the My K-cup fixture of my Keurig brewer, and was very pleased with the smooth, sweet brew.

Summary: A great break from the cheap office coffee anyway...
Text:
I don't normally drink coffee on a day to day basis as I like the vanilla flavorings and since I'm cutting down on all things sugar that is usually a no-no. That said, I was thrilled to get a chance to try this via Vine and we brewed a pot at the office this morning. Except for the boss and controller who loathe fru-fru coffee of any kind, everyone else loved it. The smell from the opened package was very pleasant (always my favorite part of the coffee experience). I felt it was a bit bitter black, but after adding some flavored creamer (yes, I did have some), I ended up with a very yummy cuppa joe.

This might not be the roast for everyone (and I see from another review there are some rather, ummm, interesting ingredients there) but this was a definite thumbs up from this office gang.

Summary: It's A Personal Flavor Choice - I Liked It.
Text:
We all know about Starbucks commitment to the environment and how the beans are responsibly grown and ethically. How about this particular coffee? I like plain Starbucks coffee, so what is `vanilla' going to "do" to my coffee taste?
I don't like the phrase "flavored ground coffee", but that is what this is.

Here are the ingredients:

Ground Coffee
Corn Maltodextrin
Vegetable Glycerin
Ground vanilla beans
Indian sarsaparilla root

Okay, very cool. How did I like it? The coffee was strong enough to make it worthy. The vanilla taste is somewhere between smell and taste, but not enough of either to really put a mark on it. If you put sugar in your coffee, you won't need it with this (if you like vanilla). For a `flavored coffee', it tastes very good. It's simply a matter of taste and choice.

Also, if you bring in your empty bag to Starbucks, they will give you a free coffee. Isn't that nice?

Summary: HInt of vanilla, strong roasted flavor
Text:
Starbucks Vanilla Natural Fusions Ground Coffee has just a touch of natural vanilla infused into the coffee. This results in a subtle vanilla aroma and a *very* subtle tinge of vanilla flavor in the coffee. Perhaps it's just me, as I've never been able to discern much of the "flavor" in the vast majority of flavored coffees offered in coffee shops or for home brewing.

That having been said, this Starbucks variety has a very distinct roasted aroma and makes a powerful cup of coffee. I personally prefer a stronger roast flavor in my coffee and found this product enjoyable; if you also prefer this style of coffee then Starbucks Vanilla Natural Fusions is certainly worth a try.

Having lived my entire life in the great state of Louisiana, I've always been partial to local coffee brands such as Community Coffee and Mello Joy. I try to make a point of buying these local brands for the simple fact that the money stays in Louisiana and both of them taste very good. To me, Starbucks has always been an overpriced and overhyped brand with a brilliant marketing strategy that put them on the map. Still, I sometimes visit the local Starbucks for a frappucino or even an Earl Grey latte when I have a bit of extra spending money on hand.

I picked up Starbucks' Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored, via the Vine program. I have to admit that it's a very good coffee as far as flavored coffees go. The scent of the vanilla intertwined with the coffee hits you before you even open the bag, but do not use that as a device of judgement until after you've brewed a few cups of this coffee.

As I've already said, the smell of vanilla is strong, but the actual vanilla flavor is very slight. In fact, the vanilla is very hard to taste at all.

I decided to brew this coffee in two separate ways: 1) Per the instructions on the bag (two tablespoons per six ounces of water) and 2) By my normal method (three tablespoons per six ounces of water).

After brewing the coffee, I drank each brewed cup in three different ways: 1) black (which is my normal method of drinking coffee), 2) with one teaspoon of cream and one teaspoon of sugar, and 3) with two teaspoons of cream and two teaspoons of sugar.

What I immediately noticed was that the bag's brewing instructions suited my personal taste best. My normal brewing method made the coffee stronger (as I like it), but didn't alter the taste at all.

When I drank the coffee black in both brewing cases, I noticed almost no difference in the taste, although the coffee's body was a bit heavier in the second brewing method. The vanilla flavor was miniscule.

With one teaspoon of cream and one teaspoon of sugar, I found that the vanilla flavor stood out a bit more, but was still fairly weak. The overall taste of the coffee was good, though.

With two teaspoons of cream and sugar, the vanilla came into its own a bit more, but could not overtake the coffee's taste itself.

Overall, this is a coffee drinker's flavored coffee. If you want a fuller, sweeter vanilla taste and less coffee taste, look elsewhere. If you only drink flavored coffees as a treat but prefer the taste of medium to dark roast coffee alone, this brew will be right up your alley.

I personally enjoyed this coffee, and plan to buy more of it soon.

For as long as Starbucks has been around and for as long as they have been selling packages of their coffee, it is somewhat suprising that they have not had a vanilla flavored product of this quality before now.  The Natural Fusions vanilla flavored coffee offers coffee drinkers the real thing.  The taste is not artificial and does not seem like an afterthought or an add-in to the coffee itself.  The scent of vanilla is not overpowering and the coffee has an extremely smooth taste to it.  Plus, it is much nicer to brew high quality Starbucks coffee at home and not have to pay the ridiculously high in-store prices for it.  This new Natural Fusions line is a fitting addition to the Starbucks family.

Summary: A Starbucks lover really likes this coffee
Text:
My wife is the avid java drinker in our family, so I requested a free bag of this coffee for her and she brewed a pot. I should preface her verdict with a proviso: although she enjoys Tully's and SBC and other Seattle brands, she is partial to Starbucks. Her review:

"Starbucks' vanilla coffee has a natural vanilla-bean flavor that subtly complements its rich, full-bodied coffee flavor rather than overwhelms it. This smooth, balanced, medium-roast blend also has a real vanilla aroma and an interesting touch of sasparilla. It's reasonably priced, so I'm likely to buy more of it."

I enjoy Starbucks coffee very much and I generally like vanilla flavored coffee. This coffee is promising but I found it a little bitter. I drink my coffee strong and perhaps I have brewed it a little stronger than it should be but I found the drink good, but rather bitter. I tried it for several days and still found the bitterness every time. I tried it with less sugar and more sugar and cream and no cream but it was still a little bitter for me no matter what.

Starbucks has many good flavored coffees for the holidays, and in general, and I drink them often. This coffee to me, didn't live up to the wonderful flavors I have drank that carry the Starbuck's name. I think the coffee needs a little more of the vanilla flavor unless Fusion means that it's just a hint, and it's a very small hint at that.

The coffee itself smells very good and it also smells wonderful when it's brewing, but it lacks a little something that would make it really good. It needs a little more vanilla and less of a bitter taste to live up to the vanilla in the name.

Summary: Smell is luscious,I think I would make it just for the smell alone
Text: If you love flavored coffees you will love this.  They do a nice job of delivering a noticeable vanilla flavor.  If you find the artificial aftertaste that most flavor coffees have unpleasant then you will probably not like this.  The smell is luscious and I think I would make it just for the smell alone.

As an addicted coffee drinker, I love trying out new flavors. I have, of course, drank Starbucks coffee before, as well as Vanilla flavored coffees. However, I have not had the two combined together into one coffee. I can honestly say that I was not disappointed with Starbucks Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored. The package is incredibly well sealed and upon opening, the scent is mouth-watering and fresh.

The amount used is the same as with any other coffee - 2 TBS per 6 oz of water. This, of course, can be adjusted for each individual's preference. The scent is heavenly, as the coffee is brewing and the taste is very robust and holds a light flavor of vanilla. The vanilla flavoring is a very gentle and light taste, almost a whisper soft hint. In addition, the taste is not bitter, but smooth and delicious. I am one who drinks with a bit of sugar and cream, rather than straight black, as well as being rather picky on my coffee, as it bothers my stomach if it is overly acidic. I had not problems, at all, with this particular coffee.

I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a full-bodied coffee with a slight hint of a vanilla taste. This makes for a delicious drink any time of the day.

Summary: OK for a flavored ground coffee
Text:
I was a bit hesitant to try Starbucks Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored, 11-Ounce Packages (Pack of 2) because I typically do not like flavored coffees and prefer whole bean coffee which I can grind myself. But for a flavored ground coffee, I suppose this one is OK.

The flavor is not bad but the aroma is intoxicating. (I think I prefer the way the coffee smells rather than how it tastes.) The lightly roasted Latin American arabica coffee beans are flavored with ground vanilla beans, Indian sarsaparilla root, and the ambiguous "natural flavor" (which also includes corn maltodextrin and vegetable glycerin). The vanilla is highlighted but not overdone.

I usually drink my coffee black and without sweetening and for my taste Starbucks Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored, 11-Ounce Packages (Pack of 2) can stand alone without additional enhancement.

The brewing recommendations suggest 2 Tbsp coffee for every 6 fl oz water. I find that a bit too much and get a smoother, less biting flavor with 1 1/2 Tbsp coffee per 6 fl oz water, but that of course is to my taste.

I do wish the coffee could be fair trade and organically grown but Starbucks states on the package that the coffee is "100% Responsibly grown. Ethically traded." At least that is something in the right direction.

Finally, I noticed a special offer on my package ~ take the empty bag of Starbucks Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored, 11-Ounce Packages (Pack of 2) to a participating Starbucks and receive a free "tall" brewed coffee. That's nice, eh?

My boyfriend and I both realized within the last year or so that we enjoyed Starbucks brand coffee best in our house, so it's one of our splurges. Since I work from home, I don't hit the coffee shops, I need to get my fix from the kitchen. He's also started bringing a travel mug to work instead of stopping off at a shop, so we find it's necessary to buy coffee we REALLY like. I was thrilled to try this and it didn't disappointed.

I expected something like the usual vanilla flavored coffee. But this was more subtle and natural tasting. It was a startling surprise from what I'm used to when buying flavored coffees. There was nothing fake or overly sweet about it. Boyfriend also said he liked it a lot, which I didn't expect since he's not really a flavored coffee kinda person. Delicious coffee, and I look forward to trying the other fusion flavors.

Summary: Typcial Starbucks, but the vanilla helps..
Text: Starbucks is notorious for having a bitter/burnt aftertaste. Such is the case with their packaged coffee as well. But the vanilla flavoring helped and made for a nice cup of coffee. I may not be the best person to review coffee since I take mine fairly sweet, but I enjoyed the cups I've had from this blend.

Loved this coffee for its smooth flavor. Not very bitter, but also very light on vanilla flavor.

Packing was very typical Starbucks and I had no issue with it whatsoever.

All-in-all, a nice smooth coffee that I would recommend.

I usually drink Farmer Brothers Coffee so maybe that's why I didn't care for this coffee at all. It was very bitter and the vanilla flavoring tasted just like that...a flavoring (and not a good one). I will keep the remaining coffee for visiters who adore the 'bucks but for us, we'll stick to our regular blend.

Summary: Good strong coffee with hint of vanilla
Text: We loved this coffee.  The coffee was a nice strong roast with just a touch of vanilla.  The smell of vanilla and coffee in the morning was a nice change of pace.  I wish the taste of vanilla had been a bit stronger, but I added some vanilla to mine on occasion and it tasted good too.

First off, a funny thing, when I was making the first pot of coffee, my husband thought maybe it had gone bad and had worms in it or something. There are white slivers/specks in the coffee grounds, which I assumed were something from vanilla beans. I hope it was, otherwise I may have made worm larva coffee! So, onto my review!

I enjoyed this coffee much more than the Melitta Cafe Collection Parisian Vanilla Ground Coffee I recently tried. Personally, I am a gold card carrying fan of Starbucks, so it shouldn't come as a suprise that I enjoyed this coffee. As a general rule, I would say if you enjoy Starbucks and you enjoy vanilla, you should enjoy this coffee. If you are not a fan of Starbucks, don't look for this coffee to be the magic sip that changes your mind.

Summary: A strong coffee that can be made to taste good
Text: I was very disappointed when I followed instructions making this coffee.  I cut down on the amount called for and the taste was great.  I never like strong coffee so it is up to ones taste.
Starbucks Vanilla flavored coffee has just the right amount of vanilla so as not to overpower the coffee taste. Even my parents, who usually drink Starbucks Breakfast Blend, enjoyed this coffee.
Not overwhelming vanilla....BUT it is natural tasting...no fake flavorings are added. It is a smooth rich coffee. I recommend it!
Great Starbucks coffee taste.  Not the first hint of vanilla.  Very disappointing if you ordered it for the "vanilla fusion".

I am so excited to see that Starbucks is coming out with flavored coffees!  My family enjoyed this Vanilla Flavored one.  It has a slight vanilla taste.  Add some vanilla creamer and you are set with one yummy drink!  My husband enjoys his coffee black and said he could taste the vanilla and it was nice that it was not so strong and over powering.  We give this coffee our thumbs up!

I am not a coffee drinker so my wife did the testing on this one. She took it to work and made up some and it was gone in a flash with everyone going hey is there any more of that special coffee that was in there????

Large group of folks downing it like wild animals. I appears that this is a keeper. Wife loved it too.

Occasionally flavored coffees can either be over the top or not flavored enough.  This is a nice mellow vanilla coffee.  Very pleasant in flavor and aroma, the vanilla does not taste terribly artificial.  The beans are not oily either.  This is a very nice soft vanilla flavor.

Right when you open this bag of coffee the amazing vanilla bean smell hits you and you think, "Man, this is gonna be a great cup of coffe!"
It smells like very fine whole vanilla beans that you've just split open. Unfortunately, that wonderful smell doesn't transfer to the actual cup of brewed coffee. (For full disclosure, I use a Cuisineart Auto drip) Once in your cup, the vanilla bean taste is way muted and kind of acidic.
On the plus side, this coffee comes ground fine, which I like. I wouldn't buy this again.
This is a great smooth coffee with a hint of vanilla flavoring.  I really enjoyed it and would highly recommend it!

Summary: The vanilla's a little TOO vanilla for me.
Text:
Yes, I know. It says "vanilla" and you expect it to taste like vanilla. What am I complaining about? Well, I was sort of expecting it to taste a bit more like coffee with a hint of vanilla, but instead this tastes like a blend of vanilla and coffee, in that order. Some people say they barely taste the vanilla. For me, it was front-and-center. It also had a sort of acid feel in the mouth, like fake vanilla, even though it says it uses real vanilla beans.

It's good coffee, though. Quite strong, quite potent, and well-ground, it works in any coffee maker and it doesn't take much to make a nice, strong cup of coffee. It's just not for me. I'd recommend cutting this with another plain coffee, to minimize that strange vanilla flavor.

If you like vanilla, you'll probably like it. Me? I think I'd rather just order a mocha.

Summary: Not much vanilla, dark roasted taste.
Text: I'll start by saying that I'm not a lover of dark roasted coffees, which is all Starbucks makes.  I find the flavor a bit harsh and bitter.  I prefer a light or medium roast, like Green Mountain coffee.  If you like dark roast however, you will probably like this coffee.  It has the typical dark, rich taste that is the signature of Starbucks.  The vanilla is very subdued.  I think most would have trouble distinguishing this from regular Starbucks coffee once it is brewed.  It does have a slight vanilla aroma however before brewing.

Summary: Would be better purchased as whole bean
Text: I love starbucks and who doesn't? I'm glad I was able to try this out but I prefer whole beans and I think it just adds that extra body of flavor. The Vanilla is is there unlike a lot of coffee that says it's vanilla, while it is not overpowering it's perfect, add a little cream and delich! The aroma is also great. This is one of the better Starbucks coffee I have had, BUT I really like vanilla flavors :)

ProfileName: Shawn Kovacich "Author and Creator of numerou...
Summary: If It's Starbucks, Doesn't It Have To Be Good?
Text:
Starbucks has created Infused coffee with natural flavors added into the coffee. The first thing that I noticed is that the coffee smelled like normal coffee with a hint of vanilla in it. Usually what I open a bag of flavored coffee, there is the over powering scent of whatever flavor coffee it is. When I brewed it, it was the same thing, just a hint of vanilla.

Just like the smell, the coffee tasted the same way. It was a good, smooth coffee with just enough vanilla to make it interesting without over powering. I recommend this to anyone that likes coffee. Was a great change from regular coffee!!

Shawn Kovacich
Author of the Achieving Kicking Excellence book and DVD series.

Summary: Not A "Starbucks" Junkie But I LOVED This Premium Coffee!
Text:
First of all, I brew a lot of teas and coffees at home. I grind my own coffee beans, have my own herb garden and use loose leaf teas 95% of the time. I live in a rural area that doesn't have a Starbucks on every corner. I have to travel 35 miles to the nearest Starbucks and even then I am loathe to spend $5.00 for a cup of coffee, Starbucks brand or not.

However, I thought this coffee was some of the best ground and flavored coffee that I had ever brewed at home. I LOVE vanilla and when you open the package you can even SEE the ground vanilla bean in the coffee.

The coffee was very smooth and sweet and I just really loved the REAL ORGANIC vanilla taste. When reading some of the other reviews, people said they couldn't taste or smell the vanilla in this coffee. That's because most people are used to artificial vanilla flavorings or vanilla extracts (i.e. alcohol based) instead of whole bean vanilla.

This coffee also has Indian Sarsaparilla Root as an ingredient. Sarsaparilla root comes from the sarsaparilla plant, a woody-climbing vine that grows in South America, the West Indies, Mexico and other tropical parts of the world. Sarsaparilla root has a pleasant fragrance and a spicy sweet taste that pairs well with the coffee bean used and the vanilla bean.

All in all this coffee makes a lovely "cuppa" and I would DEFINITELY buy this coffee and serve it again!

Happy Brewing!

This coffee is pretty good. However it is a bit stronger than I would like. It has a slight tinge of an aftertaste to the vanilla flavor.  There's not much one can say about coffee. The package opened easily and the coffee was fresh.  And I did get my normal morning jolt to help me wake up.  The titles of this flavor says "fusions" and I would say it's pretty strong on the vanilla.

Listen here. It's vanilla coffee. Do you need a review of this? Really? You do? Ok then.

You see, coffee, and I know this a shock to all of you, is a stimulant. It keeps you awake, alert, and a slave to its rhythms. Most everyone drinks it, and some people even go out on a limb to work in the coffee industry where pretentious goons stand around in circles and participate in "cuppings". But that's another story.

I cracked open this bag of coffee and, you guessed it, smelled a scent of vanilla. I looked at the bag...by golly, it's supposed to smell like vanilla! Wow! What won't they think of next? I poured some into a cup, added some water, drank it, liked it. I spent the rest of the morning bouncing off the walls and annoying my co-workers. Exactly as expected. Success!

Any more questions? No? Good.

As of this writing there have been 255 reviews posted. Sorta difficult to add anything new. I received one bag of this coffee from the Vine program. The day preceding its arrival I had brewed some French Vanilla by a brand that I regularly use and which is rated higher than Starbucks by the best known testing and rating org. This offered me an opportunity to make a somewhat taste comparison although, admittedly, the Starbucks was not French Vanilla.

In the taste test Starbucks came in second. It was neither as smooth nor as tasty as the competitor. I drink my coffee with fat-free milk and no sugar so I get a fairly good opportunity to evaluate the taste. Starbucks afficionados undoubtedly will praise this and they have every right to do so and I have no quarrel with that. However, if you are not among that group I think you will find that you would be pleased with a different brand and save a few bucks as well.

I'm not a big flavored coffee fan, but, for some reason, around the holidays it seems like I want to drink flavored coffee. Vanilla is my favorite, so when I got a chance to try this vanilla flavored coffee, I did it.

It seems to me that every vanilla flavored coffee I've tried in the past did not really have a smooth vanilla flavor that I hoped for, and this one is no different. The vanilla doesn't seem to stand out or on its own. To me, the only way I can describe it is that the vanilla tastes "burnt."

As a comparison, I tried adding Torani french vanilla syrup to my regular coffee. I liked that better. I think adding any type of vanilla flavor to regular coffee would produce a similar or better taste than buying it with the flavor already in it. So, is it really necessary to buy premixed vanilla flavored coffee?

Maybe a coffee connoisseur would be a better judge of this coffee, but to me, the occassional flavored coffee drinker, this would seem a waste of money, especially since I doubt I'll use the whole package.

I'm going to admit I'm a coffee addict but not a Starbucks fan. Assuming you like Starbucks coffee (if you don't know...just go to a shop before you buy a package), this is a drip grind, medium strength. It's definitely not a French/Dark roast. It wouldn't hold cream well at all without over-powering it.

That said, there is barely ANY vanilla taste to hit although the grounds have a strong vanilla aroma. In general, a hazelnut coffee has about 3x the flavored taste as this does. Yes I do realize vanilla is a much more subtle taste.

I would recommend either adding a drop of vanilla extract, shot of vanilla syrup or vanilla cream to your already favorite cup of joe.

I've had many different types of Starbucks coffee and there are very few I don't like. I don't really care for the more mild blends but this has a nice taste to it. I usually prefer a dark bold brew like French but this milder tasting coffee did not disappoint. It has a smooth subtle vanilla flavor and is a nice alternative for a change. The smell of vanilla fills the kitchen as it brews.

It's made with Latin American beans and has natural ingredients. Bring the empty bag to Starbucks when you're done and you'll get a free coffee.

Overall, the taste/quality i'll give 4 stars.

I love flavored coffees, but in many of them the added flavor overwhelms the coffee flavor. While I do enjoy flavored coffees, I still want to taste the flavor of the coffee, too. This Starbucks Vanilla-flavored coffee is a perfect example of a flavored coffee that comes on so strong that almost obscures the coffee flavor. Additionally, the vanilla flavor in this coffee has what I can only describe as a "chemical-edge" and aftertaste to it.

I found it undrinkable served full strength, but mixing the grind with a regular coffee before brewing tones down and smooths out the flavor to a pleasant level. For my taste, mixing it at a 1-to-4 ratio (1 scoop Starbucks Vanilla to 4 scoops regular coffee, for example) worked very well.

I drink Starbucks regularly and wondered if I would like their newest flavored varieties. I was pleasantly surprised.  The base coffee is still good and the vanilla is not overwhelming. It doesn't taste artificial and  is fairly subtle. I like that it's got the extra flavor, without being sweet (as in adding shots of syrup).  I would drink this often.

This is a very smooth, rich tasting coffee without the bitterness of less premium brands.  If one follows the brewing directions correctly you end up with a very nice cup of coffee.  One of the aspects I liked most about this particular Vanilla blend is the Vanilla was subtle and not strong.  Some who love Vanilla coffee may be put off by this, but for me it was the perfect hint of Vanilla in a smooth brew.

I'm really impressed by this coffee!  Sometimes flavored coffees feature overpowering and fake-tasting flavoring that overwhelms the taste of the coffee itself.  This is not the case with Starbucks Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored.  The beans were roasted just right, so the coffee smells rich, and when it's brewed it's just good coffee taste, without a hint of burnt beans.  The vanilla flavor isn't too heavy or so light you can barely taste or smell it.  It smells and tastes like the flavor you get from an actual vanilla bean, not a cloying, too-much fake vanilla flavor.

This coffee has a very subtle natural vanilla flavor. The vanilla is probably less strong then most vanilla flavored coffee I've tasted. The coffee flavor is very strong, in-line with most of Starbucks other coffees. This is ground coffee, not beans. The recommendations on the package tell you to use two tablespoons coffee for every 6 oz. of water. This might be too strong for newbies, so you might want to cut that in half.

Summary: Delicious Vanilla Flavor from Natural Vanilla Beans (No Fake Chemical Taste of Other Brands)
Text:
Starbucks French Roast (an unflavored, dark roast) is my favorite coffee which I buy in bean form and brew at home. I also enjoy splurging on fresh coffees from Starbucks coffee shops occasionally.

I had not tried Starbucks Natural Fusions Vanilla until now, and am happy with this because it has a good vanilla flavor.

Although I love the idea of vanilla flavored coffee, in the past, all the other coffee brands I've tasted which are served in restaurants, various coffee shops and take out restaurants (i.e. deli's and gas stations) had a fake chemical taste that I disliked. So in the past I avoided any flavored coffees.

I have also tried some creamer products with vanilla and hazelnut flavors (not made by Starbucks) but those have a sweetner in them that has a strange, too-sweet taste for me.

When I saw both the Starbuck's brand and the fact that this was a NATURAL vanilla flavor (made with vanilla beans) I decided to try it and I'm happy with it. It has a medium roast good flavor of Starbucks coffee with a vanilla taste that is not chemical-fake tasting and lacks odd aftertastes and the only sweetness is from whatever sweeter we choose to add.

Bravo Starbucks! Your "Natural Fusions Vanilla" coffee is just right!

Bonus: my package states (on the side) that if we bring the empty bag to a Starbucks coffee shop within 30 days of the "best by" date they will give us a free 12 ounce freshly brewed coffee at no charge!

Summary: Nice solution for flavored coffee lovers
Text:
I've found that Starbucks Natural Fusions has provided an ideal solution for on-the-go coffee lovers who don't want to settle for less. The ground coffee saves the time and hassle of grinding coffee beans; while the vanilla flavor adds just the right amount of flavoring. I really enjoyed the taste of this coffee!

I like that Starbucks has made it possible to enjoy a quality cup of coffee with the least amount of time and trouble. Just brew, pour and drink!

I highly recommend Starbuck Natural Fusions to everyone.
love starbucks coffee. this flavor, vanilla, really tastes good. i will definitley look for this in my local store as i want to keep some on hand to use regularly.

Summary: Pleasant, But Ordinary Vanilla Coffee for a Cold Day
Text:
The doorbell rang on a frozen rain-rattled November afternoon. The postman left a box of Starbucks vanilla flavored ground coffee.

Raggedly tired from the day, from the week, from the month, finding later autumn is rarely pleasant on its own merit, this was a good surprise. While plenty of coffee I had stocked in readiness for the first dismal days on winter, packages in the mail are like Christmas day presents. Eager, though already knowing what was inside, I smiled at the scent. Familiar. It reminded me of inexpensive coffee I bought before late novel-reading nights in college.

Brewing quickly four cups, I poured the first taste into an old mug one of my first clients gave me, the one with pelicans on a sunny pier.

Holding the mug with two hands, I sipped as anyone would hot coffee. Was it better, I wondered. No. Just ordinary. The vanilla was the same. The coffee was the same. Only the label was new. As it was already ground, it missed the freshness I can find even in any grocer who will grind the beans.

I will finish the bag, and be glad I did, but having found nothing to compel me to look for it, I won't. If you have had vanilla flavored coffee, you have had this one.

--Brockeim

First I have to say, I've always loved Starbucks' coffee. I'm a coffee lover, and how could a coffee lover not love Starbucks?

When I received a bag of the Starbucks Natural Fusions Ground Coffee, Vanilla Flavored, 11-Ounce Packages (Pack of 2) I figured it would be delicious, and it was.

Served plain (because I know there are those out there who actually don't like to load down the coffee with creamer, like I do) it has a gentle vanilla flavor. When I added Coffee-Mate French Vanilla Powdered Coffee Creamer, 15-Ounce Packages (Pack of 6) it tasted simply heavenly.

I would highly recommend this delicious infusion of vanilla to coffee lovers and vanilla lovers alike!

I brewed up a pot of this great Starbucks coffee the minute I brought it in from the  mailbox.  It's a cloudy, dreary day here in the Ozarks and a cup of this coffee was the perfect and delicious "pick me up".  Another plus is that is takes less than the standard coffee as I found out when my first pot came out a bit too strong...not a problem...just added a little water.  I would certainly recommend this Vanilla flavored Starbucks blend.  It would even make a great Christmas gift.

I enjoyed the Starbucks Natural Fusions Coffee. I wish it was whole beans instead of grounds, but that's ok... it still tasted fresh. I did find, however, that it wasn't very tasty until I put what I consider to be too much sugar in it. Typically, I only put a tablespoon, but I had to put 3-4 in this because it had an unusual taste to it. It may be that I associate vanilla with sweet, but I thought it was worth mentioning.

Really nice flavor. I have it at night for a treat before bedtime. Really nice being able to make it at home instead of having to go to Starbucks and you can make it as strong as you like. True vanilla flavor, tastes like what vanilla extract smells like. Also great for company, after all, who doesn't like vanilla flavor.... Absolutely NO bitter after taste.

About this review:
Let's face it. Any review about foods or beverages cannot be totally objective. It is usually subjective to reflect the type of taste enjoyed by the reviewer. We all have different ways to measure what tastes good to us and what doesn't. Some of us may enjoy strong coffee, while others may like it gentler. Some of us hate sour or bitter tasting coffee and others mask the taste totally by pouring so much creamer and sugar until it taste like something else.

The Coffee:
This coffee has a nice aroma when open the bag. It is unmistakably vanilla flavored coffee. I followed Starbucks instructions on the bag and added 2 tablespoons for each 6 FL of water to my coffee machine. First impression was that the coffee is on the bitter side, but tastes like the good Starbucks coffee that you drink at any of their coffee shops. I added some sugar (I'm not a fan of masking the coffee taste by adding creamer) and I took few sips. I decided to add a little more sugar (about 1 teaspoon per 6 ounce cup) and that tasted good to me. The vanilla taste is there. The strong slightly oily taste of a strong Starbucks coffee is all there. The next day I decided to make it slightly stronger, so I added 5 tablespoons for 12 ounces of water (instead of 4) and that seems to have all the elements I like about a good cup of Starbucks coffee.

Conclusion:
If you enjoy a cup of coffee in the morning and you like Starbucks coffee and you also enjoy vanilla flavor, this is definitely a coffee worth considering!

Since I drink my coffee black without any creamer or sweeteners, the taste of the coffee itself really matters to me. This vanilla-flavored coffee comes ground, which saves me the step of grinding the beans myself. Even though the beans are pre-ground, the flavor after brewing was still deep and rich, and the aromatic fragrance of vanilla still permeated after I opened the vacuum sealed bag.

The flavoring of the vanilla in this coffee is subtle and mild. I mention this because with some flavored coffees, a particular flavor can be quite distinct and strong, and dominate the taste of the coffee. For me personally, that can be a good thing or a bad thing depending on the particular flavor; I like pumpkin spice strongly flavored, while I prefer cinnamon and vanilla to be more subtle. So, if you are looking for heavily flavored vanilla coffee, expect something a bit more subtle with this flavor.

At 11 ounces, this is not a terribly large quantity of coffee for the money. That said, however, Starbucks has never been the bargain hunter's choice for economical coffee, and this is reasonably priced in relation to other speciality coffees.

My wife and I fancy ourselves coffee connoisseurs. We use an expensive drip-brew machine, cold filters, specially filtered cold water, and fresh fine-ground coffee from Pete's.

However, we also frequent Starbucks when traveling, and Seattle's Best, and even [shudder] Java City from time to time. We have exacting standards which we use at home, but we are fine with (and even enjoy), the occasional cup of Starbucks coffee, etc.

With that in mind, I when ahead and ordered this coffee sampler bag from Amazon Vine, figuring it might be an interesting trial. It was interesting all right, but only in the "i can't believe they tried to sell that as a premium new product" sort of interesting.

The grounds arrive dried out and brittle, I suspect freeze-drying was the culprit. The bag is a cheap-seal bag, glued shut, and the feel and smell of the grounds screamed "cheap."

But, even with those misgivings, I soldiered on. Maybe the coffee those grounds produced wouldn't be THAT bad ... right? It is Starbucks after all, they have a MINIMUM reputation they are trying to maintain ... yeah, I was wrong.

The coffee produced from these grounds was bitter, acrid, and acidic. The vanilla flavoring is obviously an additive that was poured on to the beans, and it also contributes to the bitter and acidic taste -- you can feel it in the back of your throat, and curdling the taste buds at the back of your tongue.

Cream and sugar mask some of the unpleasantness, but only some of it. The bottom line is this product is a cheap, freeze-dried coffee bean that has been sprinkled with the cheapest imitation vanilla "flavoring" they could find. I have tasted real vanilla bean infused flavor, and also premium vanilla extract flavor, and this was not it.

If you want vanilla flavored coffee, I would say your best bet is to buy quality beans/grounds, and brew them properly, and then add a shot or two of premium vanilla syrup, or keep a couple of vanilla beans in your coffee beans/grounds, and let the flavor infuse directly into the coffee before brewing.

Stay away from this offering from Starbucks, it is just nasty.

Summary: No Artificial Flavors and it's so delish!
Text: This coffee is great and you feel so good knowing you're not putting junk into your body!  Love it!!

As a buyer of this prior, I am somewhat surprised to see this once 1 POUND had been reduced to just 12 ounces the last time I bought. Now? Just 11 ounces? Aside from the shrinking amount of coffee for the price (leaves a bad taste in my mouth!), how about the coffee? Well, I really have a liking for anything vanilla from juicing, to smoothies and coffee too.
